intro: Hesperis chorastanica, commonly known as the Kashmir wallflower, is a flowering plant native to the Himalayan regions of India and Pakistan. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other well-known flowering plants. The plant produces showy, brightly colored flowers, typically in shades of yellow and orange, during the spring and early summer. Its leaves are basal, lance-shaped, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and branching. Hesperis chorastanica is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and for its ecological importance to pollinators.
